A teenager was reduced to tears after police seized his rally bike for causing ‘annoyance and distress’ to residents. 
Officers in Irlam used a ‘pincer movement’ to catch nuisance bikers around Prince’s Park. 
One of the bikers managed to escape, however another bike was seized on nearby Highbury Avenue after the rider ‘had chain trouble’. 
Police said the 14-year-old rider was sat crying in the back of a van waiting for a recovery truck to arrive when his mate said ‘that’s not fair’. 
The rally bike, seized on Saturday night, will now crushed unless the owner can provide ownership and pay for removal and storage costs. 
In a Facebook post, GMP Irman and Cadishead said: “THAT’S NOT FAIR. At least that is what the mate of the crying 14yr old rider (sat in the back of the van) said to us whilst we were waiting for the recovery truck. “Causing annoyance and distress to residents, not to speak of the damage to the park, didn’t seem to come into the equation as far as they were concerned. 
“Having temporarily lost our PC to a high grade job in Eccles Mark H, Paul and Phil had to be resourceful and put Plan B into operation. 
Our pincer movement in the park flushed two bikes out towards Highbury Avenue. 
“One got away but the second had chain trouble and we were able to grab hold of him. To get the bike back the rider, from Heron Drive, will have to prove ownership and pay removal and storage costs. Otherwise it will be crushed.” Read More
